Award.AwardTitle: GREPSEC III: Underrepresented Groups in Security Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal provides funding for the third GREPSEC: Underrepresented Groups in Security Research workshop, which will held in May 2017, in San Jose CA. This day-and-a-half-long workshop intended for women and underrepresented minorities in computer security and privacy, will be co-located with the IEEE Computer Society's Security and Privacy Symposium, the premier conference in security.

The broad goal of the workshop is to increase the number of women and underrepresented minorities in computer security research. Security is a wide field, encompassing network security, operating system security, language-based security, forensics, privacy, as well as legal and policy issues. The goal of the organizers is to encourage Ph.D. students who are female and from underrepresented groups to choose security as their field of specialization. Their approach is to show the wide range of problems within the field and how women and underrepresented groups are working towards solving those problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to increase interest and participation by women and minorities in the field of cybersecurity. The project organized and hosted workshops for women and underrepresented minorities on cybersecurity research. The workshops were held proximate to, and the weekend before the leading cybersecurity research conference, the IEEE Security and Privacy Conference.  The goal of the project was to introduce targeted students to current topics in research and to provide them with the opportunity to meet leading researchers and to network with each other.  The expected impact of the project was to increase the number of women and underrepresented minorities pursuing PhDs and academic careers in security and Privacy.

This grant supported two GREPSEC Workshops. GREPSEC III, held in San Jose, CA  May 20-21, 2017 and partial support for GREPSEC IV May 19 ? 20, 2019  in San Francisco CA. In attendance were the three organizers (Terry Benzel ? USC, Susan Landau ? Privacyink, and Hilarie Orman ? Purple Streak). GREPSEC III had 41 students and 14 speakers. GREPSEC IV had 35 students and 11 speakers. 

The programs and other information about the workshops can be found at:

http://www.ieee-security.org/grepsec/grepsec3/

and

http://www.ieee-security.org/grepsec/

The GREPSEC III grant received a supplement from NSA in February 2019 to help support the costs of the holding the 2019 workshop in San Francisco. Venue and supporting food, beverage and A/V in San Francisco were substantially higher than those of previous GREPSEC workshops held in San Jose CA in 2015 and 2017.

The formal part of the meeting focused on technical areas. Researchers from academia and industry presented current security and privacy research. The students ranged from first-year graduate students with burgeoning interests in security and privacy to students close to completing their PhDs in the field.

 Impact

The GREPSEC workshops have exposed approximately 140 women and minority students to the researchers and topics that are most exciting in the field.  We have structured the meetings so that the students have ample opportunity for one-on-one and small group discussions with the researchers  during breaks and receptions.  Students discover what kinds of ideas and hard problems are on the horizon.  They get to talk to other students about research projects and common problems that grad students encounter.  About half of those students also attend the Security and Privacy Symposium (S&P) that immediately follows the workshop.  They form groups at breaks, they feel empowered to ask questions, and get to know other students and researchers.

 Each of the four meetings of GREPSEC has been met with extremely positive reactions from the students and speakers.  The IEEE Computer Society's Technical Committee on Security and Privacy (TCSP), sponsor of the premier conference in the field, has always cooperated with us generously on sharing costs for students who stay over for that conference.  

Numerically, it is still difficult to measure the impact of GREPSEC on the careers of the student attendees.  In 2018 we counted the publications by attendees in the years following their attendance, and we found that there had been 33 papers published.  Two former students were on the program committees of major security conferences.   One of our previous speakers is a co-program chair of S&P for 2020, which at least shows that our workshop counts as a positive factor in career developments of junior faculty.

When we ran the numbers in June 2019, we found that GREPSEC attendees had published a total of 400 papers since the first workshop in 2013.   This included 23 papers in 2019.  The publication venues were largely those concerned with aspects of computer security and privacy (e.g., NDSS, ACM CCS, IEEE Security and Privacy, ASIACCS, etc.).  While this is an overestimate based on parsing lookups in DBLP (undoubtedly with some errors) it shows that GREPSEC students are often quite successful in continuing in their research in security and privacy.  We cannot prove that this is the direct result of GREPSEC, but it is strong circumstantial evidence that the meeting is having an impact.
